Cause it's a suicide

 *chorus (if you've never heard this song, go get it son: 1-800-suicide)*

Hey you little rich kid, what's your beef?
Come and tell the Grym Reaper all of your grief
You asked for a Benz and you only got a Jeep
Your pop's got endz, but yo he's mad cheap
Maybe you're a bastard child you think
Mom and dad are white and you're dark as ink
Maybe you're Sicilian with a tan
But you hate lasagna and the pizza man
Now you stand on the grave digga locked and
You're singing the blues about the rough life you've got
Not
You don't wanna live no more
I guess you're really ready for the grave yard tour
When you get home just fill up your windows and you doors
Turn your oven on high for about four hours
Light you a blunt, kiss your ass goodbye
You gassed yourself 'cause it's a suicide
author: Nicholas E.

description: Do you like free food with a nice cold beer? If so, you should probably check this bar out on Mondays.  Tammy makes a mean pulled pork sandwich.  The vibe is mostly unpretentious, which is unusual for the area.  Also, I like to play the basketball game in the back and bet people on the game for drinks.  It's probably not the best bar to pull chicks but who cares..I'd rather drink a beer, eat food, and watch football after work.
author: Mike L.

description:
Not bad, not great. We went here for a friend's birthday night out ... I was just along for the ride. I was pretty pumped when I saw the name was Mauna Loa -- thought I could pretend I was in Hawaii.

But that quickly changed once we got inside. Cramped. Just OK. The crowd reminded me of people I'd see in a bar in Ohio (I have friends in Ohio) and while that's not a bad thing, it just threw me off because I expected it to be some trendy Marina bar. Not to mention some slutty whore bitch who tried to pick up my boyfriend right in front of me. She didn't even seem that drunk. She bought him a beer RIGHT IN FRONT OF ME. Bitch, pull up the collar of your off-one-shoulder white trash shirt and walk the fuck away. Yeah, you heard me. OK, too bad I can't be that awesomely confrontational in person. Instead I had the birthday man go give my bf a kiss on the cheek so she got the, ahem, wrong idea. Anyway. Bitch.

But aside from that, the bartenders were all really cool and friendly and made good drinks. And you could actually hear in this place without yelling. The music/atmosphere was loud, but not PUMPIN' so conversations were possible. Unfortunately that also made conversations with the bitch and my bf possible. OK, OK ... I'll get over it ... one day.
author: Lea B.

description:
It's 2008. I think it's time we move past the cash only bar. We've put people on the moon, internet on phones, and building hybrid cars, but you can't accept a credit card???

Mauna Loa is a fun bar, but I'm just over places that don't accept cards. I don't want to carry $50-$100 in my wallet, so you can do math behind the bar.

Overall, its a down to earth bar, with a fun crowd, though it does bring out the stupid in people. I'm sure I'll be back, but can we at least agree that Mauna and many other places in the city need to catch up to TODAY!
author: Mike K.

description:
Two words:  Frat.  Party.

My roommate sometimes has sparks of  brilliance.  One night when we misguidedly found ourselves hiding from popped collars and i-banker talk (groan) on my first and last Marina pub crawl, he yelled these words into the night sky:  "This place is the shit side of a shadow!"

I don't know exactly what it means, but it somehow fits Mauna Loa perfectly (and the Marina as a whole... sorry).  Gets two stars only because the gin & tonics were strong enough to cast a haze over the rampant douche-bagdom...
author: Sarah J.

description:
The first rule of Mauna Loa Club is you don't talk about MLC...but:

There are many "Nevers" in life....MANY. Some of the "Nevers" are hard to learn. The "Never" I learned at the MLC was a valuable one. Olives, Fondue, Tequila, Purple Hooters and Jersey Dave trying to get us in a round of fisty-cuffs should NEVER happen again. 

3 duckets for the first part of the night. Otherwise, another NEVER bar in the Marina.
author: Johnny C.

description:
I'm mostly writing this review to give props to the way the bartander dealt with an annoying biligerent kid on the 4th of July.  I'm not sure what he was saying, or how this whole ordeal began, but my ears perked up when the bartender tried to kick the said kid out of the bar.  The kid's response was "Well I'm a lawyer so watch out."  Hahahaha.  He was like sure, try to kick me out and call the cops.  So the bartender grabbed the kid (maybe by the ear) and led him out of the bar.  Much to his chagrin, there just so happened to be a cop outside who promptly dealt with the a-hole.

I'm not sure what it was, but my draft Stella didn't taste that great.  It was warm.

I liked the chill atmosphere.  With three plasma tvs, It would be a good place to watch a game.

Cash Only.
author: Katie S.

description: OK bar compared to the rest of the bars in the area. It gets super hot in there cause there is no ventilation. It's cash only but they have a good amount of beers on tap.
author: Darius A.

description:
I've been looking for a foosball table in San Francisco for a month and finally found a good tournament table at Mauno Loa's. But the place only gets two starts because the table is not well maintained, it's not level, and it has the cheapest balls you can buy. They are so bad, in fact that you can't get them to stop rolling and when they are rolling it's impossible to tell which direction they will jump next. If you like foosball, as much as I do anyhow, it's not worth wasting your time here. The only thing worse than the table are the potential opponents you will find. I was hoping to find someone to give me a good run for my money, but I didn't. Ok, I'll give this a 3 star rating because I realize that I'm a bit of a foosball junkie and not everyone has my same opinion of the game.

If anyone knows of a good place to play foosball, perhaps where people host tournaments, please let me know.

Additionally, they only accept cash.
author: Paul W.

description: Great selection of beer that's on tap.  Bartenders do not skimp on the booze when making your mixed drinks.  They serve Goldfish crackers at the bar most times... Foosball, pool table, basketball hoop arcade, hi-tech jukebox, friendly people, pet-friendly... what more can you ask for?  Well, maybe more space, but really, when you're enjoying yourself that much, you don't really care if you bump elbows and make new friends;)  Definitely my first stop for drinks...sometimes my last, it depends;)
author: Kim P.

description:
It was sunday afternoon at around 3:00PM.  I'd stopped by catch the last few innings of a Giants-Dodgers game, one where the home team wasn't faring so well and the boys-in-blue were handing us our asses. The Giants were down 5-2 in the bottom of the 8th.  Ex-Homeboy turned traitor Jeff Kent had just nailed one into the bleachers.  Schmidt had held the Dodgers to two runs, but the relievers didn't look encouraging.  The possibility of Barry Bonds hitting number 714 hung like a carrot before a staduim full of fans....but nobody seemed to be holding their breath. Another forlorn face alongside mine stared blanky at the screen in front of us.   

Baseball aside, the Mauna Loa's not a bad spot to hang on a Sunday afternoon, though I've peeked in at night and seen it packed with a crowd of twentysomethings that I had no intentions of wading into.  A small horseshoe bar greets visitors, and a larger area further in back hosts a pool table and several video games.  Three well positioned LCD televisions face outward from a small inner-semicircle within the horseshoe, giving almost everyone at the bar a "best seat in the house". 

The bar had one other aspect I wasn't used to seeing....an afternoon crowd with single female patrons, and ones that were old enough for me to seriously admire.  Then I remembered...I'm in Cow Hollow. Barry Bonds never got on base that day. If I explained to any of these women that I was a 43-year old self-employed computer repairman whose biggest financial boast was positive cash flow, my batting average for the day wouldn't have looked much better.

End of the Ninth. Empty glass. Bid farewell to the other gloomy Giants fan. Exit onto Fillmore. I met eyes with the cutest woman in the place on my way out, but didn't break my stride on my way to catch the 22 Filmore over the hill. Part of me thought to myself, "If I were a younger man...".  The other half retorted with, "Who you kiddin' fool?"
author: Mike W.

description:
Dive bar and just what you would expect - marina guys, overdressed girls in white coats and cash only. Fantastic.

Except it is! I have been here a few times and the best thing about this place is the basketball shootout game and foosball table in the back. It makes it the kind of bar you could stay at all day/night. 

oh and the drinks are cheap too!
author: Jessica L.

description:
If you are 23 and under, you and your friends should go here each and every night of the week. It's  cooler that the other neighborhood 23-and under spots like the Comet Club and Bar None. The drinks are definitely cheaper that the Maitrix across the street. You can make friends with the other patrons over a game of pool or the juke box.  You may even meet a nice guy who wears a fleece and works in finance. 

If you are over 23, stay far away.
author: Colleen S.

description:
All I remember is that...Ellis K and I had some custom drink here. Some drink called...nipple something or other...and no it wasn't buttery nipple. I dunno...it just tasted really sweet. Ellis...if you remember...let me know~!! 

This place was alrite. It wasn't crowded just like the other bars we went to. The thing I like about SF is that...drinks are so cheap there. Cheaper than LA. Well...I guess...a lot of places are cheaper than LA when it comes to nightlife. Cheap drinks. Gothy yelpers. Fun. Fun. Fun.
author: Caroline Y.

description:
The only pop-a-shot game in the Marina.  A fine place to go to avoid the d-bag collar poppers overflowing from Matrix out onto the sidewalk.  Order up PBR or some Frenet shots, put some Journey on the internet jukebox and relax.  

Bonus: rarely, they open the back patio.  These are the most special days of all.
author: Rob K.

description: Dirty, Dingy, Small, Cramped, Stuffy and Cliquey place. Not very easy to meet new friendly people here, everyone seems to come with their own clique already. Pool table is a joke, situated in worst possible area. CASH ONLY
author: Tracy N.

description:
Wow, look at all these pathetic reviews about this place...talking about "ambiance" and "decor" and "decoration"...good God, it's a freakin dive bar, not Hometime!  We came here last night because it was on the way home and after about 5 seconds, I pretty much hated it.

First of all, it was after the Red Sox game and the bar was chalk full of Sox fans; one guy with a jacked up new england accent drunkenly said "Hey man?!? you sox fans?!  This is a Sox bar!!!"  Last time I checked, Mauna Loa was 3000 miles the OTHER way from Boston; and why's this city chalk full of sox and pats fans?  There should be a law where if you're a Sox or Pats fan and you leave Boston, you should get stabbed in the stomach.

The drinks came slow, cash only, crowd was a pack of franks.  The only thing good about this place are the basketball hoop in the back.  The Polynesian Gods would turn in their graves if they knew about this place.
author: Nico M.

description:
Perhaps one of my favorite taverns in San Francisco.  The Mauna Loa (or 'The Loa' or 'Den of Lovely Sin') is old-reliable.  I like this place because the owner works the bar, lives upstairs and if you're a regular, he'll take care of you in the sense that when you stroll in on a Tuesday, he gives you the story of what you did-- and marginally remember doing-- a week before...  he is a chronicle of your own drunken antics.  And by you I mean me.  We all need that kind of critical feedback-- in fact, it's a component that's missing from most bars where the staff is more interested in getting you sauced and taking your money than in either making you laugh or reconciling your demons.

This place has a tremendous internet jukebox that reaches out into the internets and brings back everything from Journey to Santana to Usher (remember Usher?  he's the dude that makes the girls wiggle and froth).  The pooltable's a bit shit as there's a column near one corner that completely prevents any kind of decent shot...  that's the kind of thing a realtor would call 'charming'.

And then there's the true gem of the Marina... pop-a-shot.  What better way to settle a wager for a beer than a bit of pop-a-shot.  Although watch out for the pop-a-shot shark.  He's like the aforementioned bar staff and is more interested in taking your money so he can get drunk.  No bueno.

The crowd here ranges from the older regulars who watch all manner of sport from NASCAR to football.  They work in the financial district and raze each other like family.  When they fade into the early evening, the rowdy crowd comes out, dudes in striped shirts and girls in tight pants.  What's not to love!  This is a great place to meet a date for the night or perhaps for a lifetime... although I can't personally recall any of the latter and quite a few of the former.  And by you in this case I mean you and certainly not me.

Cheers!
author: John R.

description:
ditto on the frat scene. didn't realize such a place existed in the marina. 3 stars on the bar itself.

am actually only writing a review bc my blackberry was stolen out of my coat pocket last night (coat was hanging on the wall quite near to me and generally in view.) i just noticed that a prior reviewer had similar experience.

so yes, fine dive bar. just watch your stuff.
author: kt s.

description:
As dive bars go, Mauna Loa gets an A. If they served something greasy like fries or hot dogs, it would be an A+. 

We went for a private thing, they treated us well. Drinks were strong and fun.
author: Amani Ellen L.

description:
Great drinks and an awesome door man! 

Totally the opposite of the stereotypical "Marina" bar - it was fun and really mellow and down to earth.  No pink polo shirts!
author: Josie C.

description:
I like this bar for everything it is and isn't: 

It is a dive...which I happen to like. 
It is pretty cheap...I bought a round of four drinks (two rum and cokes and two beers) for less than $20 on a Saturday night
It isn't pretentious....which it could try to be given the location. 
It isn't full of the typical Marina clientel...people are a little more chill.
author: Jenn G.

description:
I can't believe I have yet to write a review on this place.  Its in the rotation.  For sure.

Pop-a-shot, foosball, pool tables, juke box have all been covered.  The Loa is crowded, hot, blah blah blah.

Union Street Festival.  2002.  My job at the time forced me to work on what used to be the best day of the year.  Throughout the day I'm bombarded with drunken voicemails filling me in on the carnage the festival was inflicting on my friends.  We are talking drunken confessions of love, inappropriate gropings, and two shoving matches.  Epic stuff.

Meanwhile, I'm stuck in a fi-di office fulfilling my role as model bitch (it wasn't as glamerous as it sounds).  When I finally got out around nine, I needed to do two things:  find my friends and get drunk (catch up).

There was only one place that I'd be able to do both:  The Loa.

Its that kind of place.

My story isn't that good, but it's true.
author: Andrew C.

description:
For the sheer fact that a couple came in on their wedding night this Saturday, this place is aces w/ me.  Um, she was in a STUNNING Vera Wang gown which was a bit of a contrast from the weeds and odd Xmas decor on the wall.  But hey, it takes all kinds.  Bar tenders are on it.  Get's packed around 11ish, but if you have a spot at the bar, you are golden.  You like sports, you're gravy they have tons of TVs.  Oh and did I mention the basketball game in the back?

Yeah.  Be aware cash only..  Forget parking, hello it's the marina.  Hoof it or cab it!
author: Nicole F.

description:
The Marina-as-guilty-pleasure is an admission I will gladly make.  As long as I don't have to park there, the cabs never stop running, and I don't have to spend more then 17 minutes at the Coment Club [or any other bar, for that matter] unless I choose to, I don't really have any issues with Chestnut or Union Sts or the Bermuda Triangle.
Once you get past the bottleneck up front, it's usually not crowded in the back and there are games to play as well as a second bar, so no fighting for space to order more beers.  That said, I recall spending lots of time texting or trying to figure out why we are sitting in Mauna Loa instead of the next meetup spot -- so I guess that's saying something.

Ladies, watch out for the bathroom door: the first time I was there, some extremely drunk/rude girl decided to not only slam it open so hard it removed [most] of my toenail, she then felt the need to lecture me on why I should have worn closed-toe shoes. Thanks? Lesson learned.

Good times, Mauna Loa.
author: Kelly M.

description:
This place was pretty decent as bars go. I didn't quite get why it was called mauna loa as nothing really resembled anything hawaiian except the two hidden surf boards on the wall. Other than that, it was your typical, non descript neighborhood bar.

I liked the fact that they had real ginger ale to go with my whisky so cool beans to that.

For the most part the clientel seemed OK, though not the most social to those not in their group. Case in point: L and I were curious about the dice game some guys at the bar were playing. Neither of us were cruzin for attention or drinks or anything (I was currently holding a full beverage) and we're both cute, friendly girls. We simply walked over to their direction to ask what they were playing and if there was another set of dice. Before we could say anything, one of the guys shoved me away and grabbed the two seats next to him and said I couldn't be there because his friends were outside smoking and were coming back to their seats. Hmmm, wasn't planning on taking any seats. After that, I guess I didn't feel overly welcome if these were regulars so we ended up leaving pretty soon after. Perhaps a more friendly attitude by the customers would have been cool but at least the bartenders were nice.

So it may not end up being a go-to, but I wouldn't not go there if just for a quick whisky and ginger.
author: Allison T.

description: Other than cash only policy and dingy bathroom, liked everything about the bar. Good people, drinks, and entertainment.
author: Robbie K.

description:
So far, this is the closest I've come to the CC Club in Minneapolis.  Since nobody knows what that is, I can best describe it as the bar that Tom Arnold bummed around in before he was "famous".  Yeah, think that sums it up nicely.

Free goldfish too.  Bar popcorn has some serious competition.
author: Dave K.

description: This is the best dive bar in the Marina, hands down. The trick is you have to go on a weekday because otherwise a lot of preppies come in on the weekend. Tammie the bartender is the best. She makes great drinks and always takes care of you. She also puts out a free food platter of salami and cheese.
author: Jenny T.

description: I dig this place.  Even though there are definitely some chicks (every time) that you just want to put in a cab with a bottle of water and send them home cause they are either making a fool of themselves or acting like a classic Marina A-Hole.  But you get that anywhere.  I think that the crowd is generally pretty nice and I love getting some beer and playing the basketball shoot game in the back.  I should venture here more often.  Chill place.  And nice Bartenders which in my book can make or break a place!!!
author: Kylie L.

description:
A friend of mine loves this place, so I have to assume my last experience could have been atypical -- but it was abysmal.

I was there late on a weeknight, and they weren't super slammed so the service was reasonably fast, but the end of the evening was completely rude.  At the end of the night when it was time to pay the bill, one of the bartenders made change for $100 for my colleague to pitch in for the tab, and after doing so thought that she had accidentally given the $100 bill back to him.  She barked at him to pull the wad of cash out of his pocket, and when he said she didn't give him back a $100 bill and didn't have one (and she didn't give it back to him, I was watching) she snatched the wad of cash out of his hand and started rifling through it.  A number of us saw this happen and were dumbfounded.  To make matters worse, in her haste she accidentally flipped a few bills out of the stack onto the floor behind the bar, and had to pick them up and put them back up on the bar (hopefully they were all returned).  When she finished and didn't find the bill, she made a snide comment -- no apology in sight -- about figuring it out later, and went back to barking at us to get out of the bar (It was roughly 2am and they were trying to close the bar).  I understand that bar people need to close on-time to stay within city regulations, etc.... but really people there are more friendly ways to deliver the same message.  A friendly "thanks for coming, we're closed and you need to go but please come back soon" kind of message would have left us happier, more likely to return, and I'm sure we all would have left a better tip too.

Acting annoyed that people are still in your bar after having been rude to them and not apologizing is not going to result in a return visit.  There are too many other places to get drinks in SF.
author: Teague A.

description: We were here for literally 2 minutes last night. We walked from Umami Sushi to Mauna Loa to use the bathroom, so this review is for their bathroom. Bonus points on their wavy looking sink! I'd go to the bathroom here again! :-) The crowd seemed cool, but the girls and I were already tipsy from dinner... Or we had goggle eyes, who knows...
author: Jojo N.

description: hawaiian named bar....no mai tai!?...entrance and bar front....pool tables games back...late afternoon marina stroll continue...sunday, sunny and clear, but cold....seek shelter in mauna loa...drink of fat tire round....early and rowdy small group yelling and screaming....disturbing our late afternoon drink....
author: Hen A.

description:
After diner in the area on a Wednesday night, some friends took us here so we could hang out with each other and not deal with a big crowd.  They have foosball, pool, Buck HunterPro and PopAShot, so that means its awesome.  I'm guessing the standard crowd is similar to the guys who were wearing their suits, and look like every other Finance guy from Manhattan, but it was fine, because multiple ladies were all about my shaggy hair and beard.  Hmm...

Cheap beer and shots, and this bar doesn't try to be any classier.


But I would never go here on the weekend, or actually plan to go here; only if I was in the are would I come back.  Does that last sentence even make sense?
author: Thomas G.

description:
Mauna Loa, for those of us in the Marina who want a little spice of hipster in our nightlife.  

First of all, the cash only requirement is definitely a downer.  I don't really become a true fan of a bar until I've had to come back the next day because I left my tab open.  It's a genuine a rite of passage. 

More on the decor:  All wood, and to be honest, a bit on the cramped side.  However, when there is the right amount of people at the bar, the place is downright cozy--in a good way.  Add 100 dudes and 3 ladies . . . . less cozy and more "No I'm not hanging out with this guy 3 inches away from me, we just happen to be standing here."

A strong point in favor of Mauna Loa "Club" (Club?  When did that happen?), is the games.  It has the full assortment of pool, foosball, and the kicker, the recently upgraded basketball machine.  Makes for good times, especially when dudes get beat by their significant other on the basketball machine and have that "I could have dun' better if I wanted to" face going.

Bottom line:  When the number of people at the bar is right, not too few or too many, and you have enough cash on hand (read: before the strip club people), a good place to get your drink on, play some games and chill in a place that doesn't try TOO hard to be cool.
author: Jordan J.

description: When I lived in SF I was rarely in the Marina district so I wasn't sure what cool dive bars they have in the area.  While visiting last month we stayed in this area and luckily  found this great bar.  There aren't many.  We met up some old peeps and had a great time.  Our bartender was awesome.  I cannot remember her name but she was great.  A lovely city, $5 Fat Tires, a game of pool and great conversations.  Ideal.
author: Grace L.

description:
me (to group):  where are we going?  i'm think i'm ok w/anywhere, as long as it's not somewhere like circa.  i'll have to kill myself if that's the case...

colin:  i think it's called mauna loa?  they have a pool table, foosball...
me:  FOOS...!?!?!  (i covered my mouth mid-sentence b/c i realized how loud i was.)

i'm an avid foosball player.  my office has a table.  i usually play four times a week w/my boss and co-workers at the end of the day.  it makes me feel like i have purpose in my life.

the crowd wasn't too diverse, unfortunately.  ...the awesome bartendress served me a near-clear cranberry grey goose, which was all i needed for the time that i was there.

colin and i headed straight for the foosball table.  we successfully held the table down for a pretty long time.  thanks for being a great foos partner, colin!  :)

foosball table, strong drinks, forgetting where i was = a jewel in the marina rough.
author: Ting A.

description: The Blonde bartender with the beautiful S.F. boobs is a sweetheart. No attitude either which is rare for the neighborhood. Nice to see a bartender in the marina who isn't jaded. Other than her the place is kinda forgettable. Just a simple dive bar among the myriad of  kidney killing liver losing locales.
author: santiago g.

description: I just discovered that one of the bartenders (possibly the owner?) is a fan of Magnum, P.I. and on Thursdays - from 3pm to 6pm - they show back-to-back episodes of Magnum, P.I. (played off DVDs).  That's enough to entice me to drop in and tip a beer with the regulars on Thursday afternoons.
author: Alec B.

description:
This bar is for those who are seeking some suds, billards, and a juke box full of sing-able hits.  It is a kind of like a dive bar that caters to locals-only, but invites outsiders to be a part of their cool club.  

My tip is to head directly to the bar to amply liquidify yourself and then make a bee-line to own the juke box.  Ply yourself with drinks and fire up some hits.  Once you properly take care of the music, then mingle with the crowd and you'll find some bad-ass cool cats, lucious ladies, and a few of those who cross both lines.

Good times, Mauna Loa.  It rocks.  Can't wait to go back.
author: Bob D.

description: A buddy of mine recently had his "Guess What? I've Decided to Totally Ruin My Life by Marrying Some Chickie I Just Met AND We're Moving to L.A." party here. Okay, maybe that's not what HE called it, but it's what 82.57% of us in attendance were thinking. Anyway, I'm not a full-on Marina-hater. It's definitely not part of my favorite City boroughs list, but I'm a relatively tolerant fella. That said, if you happen to be one of those who despises all things Marina, do not despair. This bar is actually quite fun. It has a relaxed, laid-back atmosphere, cheap drinks, and is group-friendly, so there's mass appeal no matter how much Haterade you've been sipping.
author: Gregor G.

description: Thank you Tammy for the snacks and strong drinks. "Stinky Cheese" Tuesdays are great at Mauna Loa: free nibbles of cheese, crackers, and slices of meat (if you are carnivorous). I have passed this place many times and it is usually packed, although there were only 4 or 5 other patrons when we were having our Tuesday night happy hour. HH drinks are $3.50 and they pack a little punch! I will be hanging out here more.
author: Theresa T.

description: Went here with some friends and had a great time. We meet a lot of really cool people and the staff great as well. My work meeting the next morning was not fun but I'll be back
author: Mike H.

description:
we stopped in before the yelp event at kasa.

this hawaiian themed spot has lots of games like bball, deer shooting, fooseball, a pool table, and i think i saw pinball? other than that, it's a bar.

oh yea, the men's bathroom is real small with no door lock, so i was walked in on a few times. though there's a toilet and a urinal so when the drinks are really flowing you can prob go 2 at a time.
author: Ameer N.

description: From the outside on weekend nights, this place looks like it houses one of the most obnoxious crowds in the Triangle area; however, I was pleasantly surprised to find it inviting and fun, in a juvenile, fake ID-having kind of way.  They have foosball and a basketball game at the back of the bar along with a bunch of kids getting sloppy playing quarters.
author: Rick H.

description: (One of) the only divey bar(s) in Cow Hollow.  Nice semi-circular bar serving fairly cheapy drinks (PBR on tap) with games on the tubes above.  I'm not a big fooseball guy, so besides the Pop-a-shot game in the back, the middle and back 'game' sections of the joint are kind of beat-up and whack (small pool table & pinball machine, dark and cramped with nowhere to sit and not much room to move around), and the bathroom has no lock on the door, so for me, it's all about the bar.  Can get crowded on Fri/Sat nights, but this is a great place for Marys on Sunday AM when you just want to watch the game and figure out where it all went wrong (right?), without dealing with the cheesedick sportsbar crowds @ other places.
author: Ryan W.

description: Pop A Shot...big buck hunter...this place is my fav..only downer is its CASH ONLY...thats why its not a 5! Wayne the bouncer is crazy good at Pop A Shot..seen him get like 120!!
author: Kevin B.

description: I have to say, I like this bar. It is filled with a bunch of boners, but you'll have that. This bar is dirty, they serve crap whiskey and they have a pool table. What's not to like about this place. I had no desire to talk to anyone, so I just sat back, got drunk and rocked out to the Stones.
author: Michael E.

description: A slightly more pretentious version of Trad'r Sam's, I went here with three friends only to find myself soon locked in a cage of Marina dudes with vertically striped shirts. I panicked, downed my beer, got the hell out of there, hoping my friends would execute a recon. I suppose this place is alright. It deserves another try next time I'm in the vicinity--would be a good stop on a bar-hopping expedition.
author: Patrick G.

description:
The only dive bar I go to... ever... 
Manual: Come in before 10pm, get your seats , better between the bar and the window, so you can see everything and won't be crowded, order drinks and enjoy the freak-show which starts at  around 10:30 pm. You will see best that marina has to offer: cute drunken college girls, loud frat dudes, sleek cougars, wannabe cools with stunna shades on :-) Never disappoints!!!
author: Irina L.

description: The Loa has been a home away from home for years.  I have met so many wonderful friends there.  Renee is the owner, a former teacher, and mentor.  He always welcomes you like you are one of his own.  His son, Curt, runs the place and treats you like family.  Tammy, one of the best bartenders in SF, offers up chili hot dog Mondays and fancy cheese plate Tuesdays.  It's a great afterwork bar to converse with the locals about business and sports.  Um, can I say....  not only do they have pool, Buck hunter but pop-a-shots.  Fun for all sports fans.  Decent wine too.  It's a great place to meet work colleagues, friends and first dates.
author: Angel L.

description:
We came here after our company Christmas party. It's a cool place, especially because of the fooseball, pop-a-shot, and gun slinging game. 

The bar tender was okay, and the prices weren't too bad. Nothing to write home about. 

I'd come back just to play big buck hunter!
author: Josh M.

description: The epitome of the Marina "Fake Dive" bar.  A regular haunt.
author: Jay W.

description: I'm not going to be one of those people that says "OMG I love this bar because its a dive bar and not like those other Marina Bars". If you're in the Marina, you know what you're getting yourself into. Mauna Loa is the same... Johnny I-Banker to your right, Tommy Frat Business Guy to your left. The thing that makes ML great is the Pop-A-Shot machine in the back, and cheap PBR. The men's bathroom smells like a hamster cage, which among the previously mentioned items, it what makes this place great.
author: Heavy B.

description:
i came to mauna loa on a tuesday night. i felt like it was 10pm but to my surprise it was only 8. hahaha. sooooo there werent that many people in there. we walked in and the bartender immediately asked what we wanted. thank you kind sir, how courteous of you!

pbr on draft. thank youuuuu!
pool table.
cute bathroom. the doors make me laugh.
hoops in the back.
2 bars. but when i was there 1 was closed.
some seating.
its divey. but its cute divey.

thank you mauna loa for allowing us to kick it.
author: A. V.

description:
WHAT THE HECK? 

This place is too ghetto for me, and it's located IN the marina... does that mean I'm snooty, like a typical Marina beb?
author: Jennifer S.

description: I guess it's ok --- if you're the type of person who enjoys being crammed into a smelly, poorly designed hallway with a large number of former and current frat dudes and the dumb sorority girls they try to score with.
author: Sarah P.

description: Mauna Loa has a special place in my heart because once, on my way out of Bar None to this fabulous bar, I met a guide who was willing to show me the way and instead walked by it four times and made me fall in love with him as he did it. No really that's how we met. Without that affectionate association I give it a solid three stars. The cash only thing boggles my mind, as if they really don't get enough revenue to pay whatever fees they need for a credit card machine. But the bartender was awesome and really great with keeping all the drinks full, which unfortunately sets it apart from lots of bars around here. The crowd is class-A marina douche, but luckily I crave that kind of interaction every once in a while, so it works out. Plus, I go there, so what does that make me?
author: Katie T.

description: Hit this with my boys last night and kicked some ass in basketball, even with my girly shot.  The bartender was impossibly nice; we felt bad she had to suffer the ramblings of a lonely soul sitting at the bar, but we had to be in the back with the games.  The somewhat confusing and discordant decor-- Can-Can dancer?  Check; Mauna Loa hawaiiana?  Check; Kentucky Derby memorabilia?  Check! --added to the charm.  I suspect, however, that as would be true for most Marina bars, I liked this place in part because it was an empty Monday night with just me and my charming companions.
author: sunny d.

description: Forget what happens just a few blocks away around the Matrix and Balboa ect... This place is  a nice spot to cop a seat at the bar and try and get the birthday girl drunk so that she will get the naked on with you.... while she did get drunk, she wasn't willing to fuck... at least the bar was nice and not to expensive.
author: Thadd L.

description: You have to be really wasted to enjoy this place... hence the stars. They have one of those new-fangled jukeboxes that lets you download songs.
author: Nick K.

description: As my friend put it, "it smells like poo". She also found a suspicious looking hair on her pint glass. On the plus side, they do have foosball and a hoops game and some decent beers on tap. However, if you plan on dropping the kids off at the pool, you should look elsewhere. The tiny mensroom doesn't have a lock on the door allowing for complete viewing...
author: Nicolas H.

description: We're not talking chart-topping good times here, but this bar ain't bad.  There's usually enough elbow room--more than the neighboring bars.  Less pretentious, early to late 20-something crowd.  Tee-shirt and jeans night in the Marina....and a vicious moving-hoop basketball arcade game in the back.
author: Robby T.

description: Another bar I visited during the afternoon with a large group.  Very fun because of the pool, golden tee (!) and other games.  Not sure what it is like in the evenings, though as I walked past it one evening people were spilling out of the doors singing.  I'm in!
author: Beth G.

description: Hitting up the Mauna Loa on a weekend brings with it a whole host of disadvantages- packed bar, "interesting crowd"... in general... meh (like a number of Polk street establishments).  That said, hit up the Mauna Loa on a weeknight and it turns into one hell of a drive bar/great place to be. On Monday nights, Rory (avid Giants fan, cool chick) serves up strong drinks quickly. Free hotdogs if you arrive before 9.  Juke box is cool- you can download any song you want and on the weeknights there is very little waiting for your songs to come up. Reasonable priced pool table and b-ball games make this a fun place to hit up after work.
author: Jenni D.

description: what a fun place!  I really liked how low key this bar is, though once it did hit the witching our it got CROWDED!  Drinks were awesome, bartenders were awesome!  and I loved the little basketball game in the back!  fun times!!
author: Michelle B.

description: Horribly rude bartenders.  I will never step foot in this place again, as it is clear that the employees do not value their customers in any way, shape, or form.  The bartender cussed out the girl next to me for simply asking why they had served her group of friends warm jaegger bombs.  Her group left, and so did mine as the behavior of the staff was repulsive.  This place is AWFUL!
author: Leigh-Anna B.

description: A darn good dive bar in Cow Hollow.  Much better to hang here than most other places in the hood.  There is a good selection of beers on tap, pool, a jukebox, and other bar games in the back.  Watch out for Melinda, she will hussle you at pop-a-shot.
author: Dave L.

description: Most of the Fillmore Chestnut bars are the same old yuppie stuff.  Not Mauna Loa.......They have a special every day and they have Trumer Pils which is by far the best up and coming beer on the market.....THE BEST part of all is the backside with the Fooseball table and Basketball shoooting game.   My boy Lumbo went for 81 just like Kobe last year.  Dont cheat by just banking them in and having the score machine cheat for you.  I definetely suggest this place to start off your night before going to cut a rug on the dance floor at a club.  With a good crowd and great games to keep you busy, Mauna Loa is the place to be.
author: Harry E.

description:
Pro: getting drunk and battling your friends on the fooseball table

Con: getting drunk off of drinks that resemble the ones you mixed when you played "bartender" in 10th grade

Pro: being a dive bar makes everything feel unpretentious, like you don't have to fit some standard of clientele...you can get shamelessly shitfaced.

Con: getting shamelessly shitfaced in front of some creepy old dudes who want to show you their apartment because they "have artwork that might inspire you"......???
author: Nicole R.

description:
strong drinks, mellow crowd, good music.  what more could you ask for?  maybe some cute girls, but then again you don't usually go to a dive bar with high hopes.  fun games in the back to keep you and your drunk buddies entertained.

ADDED BONUS- if you're bored of the inside games... there is a metal grate on an incline out front on the sidewalk.  if it's raining, or if you have a bucket of water to dump on the grate- it becomes slippery.  if you have a drunk friend with bad balance named el doooostay, you can convince him to try to slide across said grate.  if you're lucky, his feet will fly out from under him and he'll land flat on his back with an earth shattering thud.  if he's lucky, he'll only have some minor internal bleeding and a mild concussion.
author: Sean L.

description:
Three stars for the overall dive bar status (sometimes leaves you without much about the place to rate), but 4 stars because of the WEEKDAY EVENINGS that can be had here. The regular bartenders are friendly, engaging people, and the regulars are a world apart from your typical B&T and Marina popped-collar scene that you'll encounter after 8 on Fridays & Saturdays.  If I had to rate it based on the weekend, I wouldn't even bother with one star, but I can't knock the place for what I have experienced outside that short time frame.  My only real complaints have to do with the men's room:  it smells of sweaty animals, wet buffalo and old feet (the experience is more nauseating than it sounds), and it's tiny size makes it next to impossible to smoke crack in privacy.  

A universal comment: I see two completely different neighborhoods occupying the same space depending on whether it is a Tuesday afternoon or a Saturday night.  To each their own, of course... while the weekend nights there appeal to a certain crowd, you can't beat pop-a-shot, foosball, and big buck hunter all within 10 feet of each other. Serving your inner-child is never a bad thing! (unless you try cramming yourself in there late on a weekend night, which I wouldn't suggest as the countless varieties of axe body spray lingering in the air, fighting their epic battle for dominance and attention in your breathing space, will make you throw up in your mouth just a little...)
author: Bre L.

description: I'm only giving this place a few starts because it makes me realize my age. And if you go at the wrong time (i.e. Midnight) just forget about getting inside without becoming a sweat sandwich. I always forget that it's cash only too. I guess you have to be pretty wasted to have a good time here, and in case you need an example of this, just check out my photo above there with Todd.
author: Amanda C.

description: The Mauna Loa Club is a fun place to hang out on a weekend for Tornado foosball.  The location is very lively, and has a fairly good amount of challengers who think they can play better foosball with more drinks.  I took one star off, because many people spill their drinks on the playing field, that I have to clean up on the weekends.  Still, if anyone is interested in playing or practicing foosball, then I will not say no.
author: Alex T.

description: Nice place, great location. The staff is friendly and you get goldfish crackers when you order a drink, which is a bonus in my book.
author: Charissa W.

description: This place has a good East Coast vibe. Lots of beautiful people, but not too pretentious. I dig the  staff who doesn't let anyone take themselves too seriously.  I applaud the fact that the bouncer lambastes and turns away anybody who he plainly doesn't like.  Thank goodness all the other 'Triangle' bars attract the annoying Marina folk.
author: Todd J.

description: I don't really know how people still flock to this place.  Maybe the lighting is just a little to high, because you can see how dirty the place looks.  The drinks are okay, but I never seem to enjoy the crowd that is there.
author: Robert R.

description: Well, I'm 24, so I guess that makes it my "scene."  I would argue that anyone who stays young at heart would enjoy shooting some hoops, kickin' it  foosball style, blowing up rabbits on the buck shot game, and all the while enjoying a nice variety of brews.  The crowd seemed decent- it was actually slightly older/mature than I expected.  It's a clean, almost refreshing dive.
author: Erica L.

description: Very nice staff, cool people, laid back and a pool table, what's not to love?
author: Moi S.

description:
cash only, but great games, pool, b-ball, and both golden T and the EASports version of it! 
very relaxed atmosphere. I like it!
author: Scott K.

description: Union Street generally annoys the hell out of me, but for some reason I've always had a soft spot for Mauna Loa.  It's nothing special inside -- a standard dive bar with a pool table.  It gets very crowded on the weekends, but the crowd isn't the same B&T bunch that you find down the street at BarNone, so it's tolerable.
author: Andrew E.

description: A really great place if you're looking for that recent post-college crowd.  Fun groups of people, friends, pool, deer-hunter, foozeball.. it's like Chuck-E-Cheese, but for the young-20's crowd.  Very social.  Definitely a place I'll want to check out again.  It was not overly crowded and packed... you could walk around in the place, but still a good presence.  Drink specials depending on the day of the week - Saturdays are $5 Asian Bulls (Asian Vodka and Redbulls).. pretty strong.  Definitely the 'marina crowd' at this bar... the transvestite playing pool stood out a little bit.  Cash-only bar.
author: Jason R.

description: The third stop of the series.  Maybe I was a bit buzzed at this point, but I was almost sure this was a dive bar in the Marina.  Yes, a dive bar.  Replete with cheesy, dated, faux wood paneling and mismatched decor, none of which served any theme even remotely Hawaiian.  With the arcade games in the back it was kinda like a poor man's Dave & Buster's-but just the Buster part.  Drinks are not too dive priced-spent my last $16 on a draft and two shots.
author: Sam N.

description: This is on the top 10 for 2 reasons...1)they serve car bombs 2) they have a foosball table!
author: Sarah D.

description: Star ding for being full of 23 year old bubbleheads, but I am a sucker for foosball and pop-a-shot!
author: Max C.

description:
Yeah this bar smells bad, doesn't accept plastic, is filthy  - but there is Hot Shots in the back.  Everything else is forgiven and forgotten.

Does anyone else find it amusing that Mauna Loa calls itself a club?
author: AngelaS F.

description:
i'm totally with blake on this one:  this bar makes me want to carve my eyes out with a spoon.  i have friends who loooooove it and i can't for the life of me figure out why.  

drinks?  notsomuch. 

crowd?  notsomuch.  

ambiance?  notsomuch.  

best part of the night?  going somewhere else.
author: nic f.

description: Pretty good space. Really cramped getting in the door past the bar. Back is usually less crowded and it's fun when there's live music. Big singles beat, some seating at bar and back. I seem to end up here when I'm in the Marina dancing :)
author: Mel H.

description: If my best friend's wife didn't bartend there, I would honestly never set foot in this joint again. I hate to sound like a typical Marina-basher, but jeez - you really feel like you're on another planet in this place. It's quite an incredible petri dish of whiteness in there, folks. That being said, if you do happen to hang out here, go directly to the back bar and say hiya to Karen - she's the bomb, yo. :)
author: Justin H.

description: I like to come here as soon as I get tired of the people at the Matrix.  Good jukebox, well mixed drinks, variety of beers and moderate prices.  Wish it wasn't a cash only bar though.
author: Medwin M.

description:
Second only to "Asqew," (see previous Yelp Review) "Mauna Loa" is the most difficult word to spell.

I used to come to Mauna Loa a lot, right after graduating from Bar None.  But now that I'm somewhat older and a whole lot wiser--and refuse to wait in bar lines--I give it wide clearance.  

If I were to be younger, and more naive, and maybe blonder, and definitely more patient, I might go to Mauna Loa.  I've found that it's especially good for when you are planning to "accidentally" run in to someone from your recent past, and for when you're looking for a plethora of bar games such as Pop-a-Shot, Golden Tee, and Liar's Dice.

I also get the feeling that the staff are pretty darn nice to and tolerant of the crowd, so cheers to them.
author: Hannah J.

description: I was pleasantly surprised by this place.  A good selection of micro-brew beers on tap, not overwhelmingly yuppie (at least on a Tuesday night), and having pool, foosball and a basketball shooting game is a definite plus.
author: Karla R.

description: Will never know what made us decide to check out the Marina after the Mission... can only guess it was the influence of my bud's fancy jacket and shirt trying to look dapper and slick... but for whatever reason, after checking out Matrix for laughs and leaving with a much more needed level of raunchy down and out fun, we were luckily corralled here by some cute suburban kiddies with crazy ski-bum-trashy pals celebrating one of their birthdays, too.  Well.... it was fun... pool table (yipee) and basketball games, juke box and just a fun dive.  So... don't plan on being back in the neighborhood for a night out... but great for a little almost-raunchy (ala marina style) silly fun.
author: Today Y.

description: All praise to its name...I've been going to the Loa for almost 6 years and I still love it. Pop a Shot in the back, Wayne at the front door, solid bartenders who aren't afraid to throw a few back with you and a crowd that  is good looking and likes to party...nothing but good times, even when it's crowded to hell.
author: Mike P.

description: A nice cahnge of pace, if you are looking for an atmostphere that is not duplicated anywhere else in the Marina. The cash only aspect is a bit tedious, but they have some pretty attractive drink specials and they have Journey on the Juke box. That alone will get this Marina establishment and above average rating.
author: Tabor, S.

description: Oh, Mauna Loa.........the last time I was there I kicked some douchebag's ass at Big Buck Hunter.  Chicks rule.
author: Shauna H.

description: This is my absolute favorite weeknight Marina hangout.  Drink specials abound, I heart internet jukeboxes, the bartenders are friendly, they have Big Buck Hunter, and there's never a problem getting up a game of pool.  It's not pretentious, and they have free, all-you-can-eat hotdogs on Monday nights (not that I eat them but it still cracks me up).  I love dive bars and I love this place.
author: Dale M.

description: This place is a great time.  Usually attracts a mellow--wanting to party kind of crowd.  I always have fun there....even though its in the marina
author: Laura J.

description: It can get a little too crowded but I always have fun at this bar.  Plus they have pop a shot.
author: b s.

description: As a former Cal student I almost always run into alumni at this place.  I love the Fat Tire specials during the week, the games in the back and the overall vibe. Its dark and cozy and there is neat stuff all over the walls. The vibe is so mellow and its a refreshing change from the crowds further down the street.  Make sure you have enough cash since they dont take cards.
author: Cassandra E.

description: I've always loved this place for being the low-key alternative to the rest of the bar offerings on Fillmore.  It used to be primarily a neighborhood hangout, but it seems as though word has spread and the crowd seems to turning into more singles-on-the-prowl than it used to be.  It's still the most relaxed venue in the area, though, especially mid-week.
author: Zach L.

description: Hasn't changed at all in at least the fourteen years that I've lived here and in this case that's a good thing. The staff is always friendly and you won't sit around with an empty glass in front of you for long.
author: Dan L.

description: Jill and Jen are the best 2-woman bartending crew in the city.  Lately this place has been filled with too many striped shirts, but is always a good time.  Not really a dive anymore, but still a bar that is less marina than everywhere else in the neighborhood.  Grab a glass of goldfish and get ready to get hammered.
author: Jay T.

description: fun little dive bar, i always seem to have a good time here (from what I remember haha).
author: Chrissy A.

description: how could you not love this place? i love the 'Loa! its small, laid back, sometimes loud and always fun. you just want to sit here all night drink with your friends and maybe catch a game on the TV. its not fancy, just a simple place for drinks. good location too.
author: Michelle I.

description:
for the new year's resolution, i was determined to explore the districts of SF that i havent really visited too much. so, despite all my reservations about it, we decided to try out a bar in the marina. i've always avoided this neighborhood like the plague because the bars there attract the worst people ever. well, within seconds of walking into the Mauna Loa, i could see why i've been avoiding this area. i felt like i walked into a frat party from hell. everyone there was super cheezy. the kind of people who used to be a fratboy/jock/cheerleader and now have lots of money and like to brag about it to everyone around them. within a few mnutes of being there, a fight almost broke out. of course, in the end there wasn't an actual fight, instead it was just some testosterone fueled bullshit where people can act all badass and then go home later and brag to all of their friends how they almost beat someone up. ugh.

the thing is, the bar itself here was actually pretty cool. nice bartenders, decent beer selection, foosball table... the place would actually make a decent bar if it wasn't for all the idiots that were there. after one drink, richard refused to go back inside but the rest of us toughed it out and had another drink. then, we got the hell out of there.

also, i'm still not sure why this place has a hawaiian name seeing as there is nothing else hawaiian about it.

(my resolution this year is to visit 50 new bars in SF.  read about it at: http://fiftybars.thisisvlad.com )
author: vlad k.

description: Although I know people who enjoy this place, I have a hard time finding any redeeming qualities about the bar or its patrons at large. It strikes me as the epitome of all that is irritating about the Marina. When I walk in here late on a Saturday night, I immediately have to ask myself, "Am I a chump or a clown?" Because those are the only two options, man.
author: Eugene P.

description: Okay, the marina is like a huge frat party.  one of those themed frat parties you pay $10 for and are transported on a bus to some huge field with jungle juice and shit.  The theme of this party is "businessmen gone wild".  at one point, we saw a drunk girl screaming at her boy friend, who had obviously drunkenly cheated at her... she pushed him into a chain link fence.  Her friends were laughing and talking about pizza orgasmica.  it was awesome... that's where my night in the marina turned around.  after that, a friend of mine got a bucket of water dumped on her head out of a second story window.  she took a picture of their address and will notifying the authorities.  And then, we found the Mauna Loa.  What a fun place!  Am I in the Marina, or did i just step off my private jet for a relaxing vacation in hawaii?  I tell you, I'm not sure.  all I know is that it wasn't overcrowded, and we could hear each other talk.  It was nice.
author: Caleb D.

description: 3 words.  pop a shot.  it's one of the best bar games around, and there aren't many places that offer it in the city.  this bar is a nice pick for a casual night out with friends - good location, nice bartenders, bar games galore (did i mention pop-a-shot?), and a great jukebox.
author: Jan W.

description: The drinks are pretty stiff here, and there are a number of games (Golden Tee, Pool, Foosball, basket-toss, etc) to play, but when the space gets crowded (as it does on Friday/Saturday nights) using them quickly becomes impossible. The crowd is usually attractive mid-late 20-somethings to 30's, plenty of outgiong and interesting folks all around. Of course, it's not the Matrix Fillmore, so the level of pretention is a bit lower, which is rare in this part of the city.
author: Alex G.

description: If you are looking for another place you would call fraternity central, this is a good destination.  However, I would not put it in the same level as Bar None.  The people are a bit more respectable and during off hours, I have actually enjoyed the clientele.
author: Matt J.

description: this place used to be 4 stars.  now, it is overflowing with obnoxious people.  i always seem to see a hen party there when i go.
author: Tim G.

description: the lady bartender always remembers me when i come in, and that's like never, and she never charges me.  bartender courtesy, thx!
author: Pickle R.

description: Best dive bar in the area. Staff is cool...they treat regulars well. Always sports on the plasma and good music. Go Monday-Thurs to avoid the B&T crowd.
author: Dirk S.

description: The women bar tenders there are disgusting pigs.
author: Dan G.

description: booze is booze, however this bar has not only pool table, big buck hunter, but pop shot basketball game! yes please!!
author: Jess L.

description: The female bartenders are adorable and totally fun. I have to say though.. the clientel on a thurs-sun are totally yuppies, and I know it's the Marina, but seriously, get over yourself and have a good time. The men will hit on you wether you in a turttle neck or a Jlo dress. The pool table is free. The juke box has an amazing selection. The drinks are reasonably priced, and they have a fun basketball game in the back. Restrooms are clean. Tuesday has free chili dogs. I say check it out, you may find what your looking for. If you a female your in luck, you won't go home alone, or wake up with "what the fuck was I thinking" there are a plethora of gorgeous young men. If your a guy, your in luck, plenty of self concious women who want to suck dick are present, get yourself ready for a good time. GLBT.. ehh not so much. I've met a few hot lezzy's there, and a few gay cutie boys, but it's very midwest in a way. But honestly it's so marina dive bar that it's perfect. The unfortunate part is that the waitresses are so cute and kind, yet they have to deal with BS. Fun for out of towners, and youngin's
author: Katie M.
